pageProps.body:
Trigonometric Substitution

Integrals involving a2−x2a^2-x^2a2−x2

Suppose you are faced with an integral whose integrand contains the term a2−x2a^2-x^2a2−x2, where aaa is a positive constant. Observe what happens when xxx is replaced with asin⁡θa\sin{\theta}asinθ:

(Replace xxx with asin⁡θa\sin{\theta}asinθ)

a2−x2=a2−(asin⁡θ)2a^2-x^2=a^2-(a\sin{\theta})^2a2−x2=a2−(asinθ)2

(Simplify)

=a2−a2sin⁡2θ=a^2-a^2\sin^2{\theta}=a2−a2sin2θ

(Factor)

a2(1−sin⁡2θ)a^2(1-\sin^2{\theta})a2(1−sin2θ)

(1−sin2θ=cos⁡2θ1-sin^2{\theta}=\cos^2{\theta}1−sin2θ=cos2θ)

=a2cos⁡2θ.=a^2\cos^2{\theta}\text.=a2cos2θ.

Example: Area of a circle

Verify area of a circle of radius aaa is πa2\pi a^2πa2.

Solution

The function f(x)=a2−x2f(x)=\sqrt{a^2-x^2}f(x)=a2−x2​ describes the upper half of a circle centered at the origin with radius aaa.

The region under this curve on the interval [0,a][0,a][0,a] is a quarter-circle. Therefore, the area of a full circle is

4∫0aa2−x2 dx.4\int_0^a{\sqrt{a^2-x^2}}\,dx\text.4∫0a​a2−x2​dx.

Example: Sine substitution

Evaluate ∫1(16−x2)32 dx\int{\frac{1}{(16-x^2)^{\frac32}}\,dx}∫(16−x2)23​1​dx.

Solution

The factor 16−x216-x^216−x2 has the for a2−x2a^2-x^2a2−x2 with a=4a=4a=4, so we can use the substitution x=4sin⁡θx=4\sin{\theta}x=4sinθ to evaluate the integral.

It follows that dx=4cos⁡θ dθdx=4\cos{\theta}\,d\thetadx=4cosθdθ. We now simplify (16−x2)32(16-x^2)^{\frac32}(16−x2)23​:

(Substitute x=4sin⁡θx=4\sin{\theta}x=4sinθ)

(16−x2)32=(16−(4sin⁡θ)2)32(16-x^2)^{\frac32}=(16-(4\sin{\theta})^2)^{\frac32}(16−x2)23​=(16−(4sinθ)2)23​

(Factor)

=(16(1−sin⁡2θ))32=(16(1-\sin^2{\theta}))^{\frac32}=(16(1−sin2θ))23​

(1−sin⁡2θ=cos⁡2θ1-\sin^2{\theta}=\cos^2{\theta}1−sin2θ=cos2θ)

=(16cos⁡2θ)32=(16\cos^2{\theta})^{\frac32}=(16cos2θ)23​

(Simplify)

=64cos⁡3θ.=64\cos^3{\theta}\text.=64cos3θ.

Replacing the factors (16−x2)32(16-x^2)^{\frac32}(16−x2)23​ and dxdxdx of the original integral with appropriate expressions in θ\thetaθ yields:

∫dx(16−x2)32=∫4cos⁡θ64cos⁡3θ dθ\int{\frac{dx}{(16-x^2)^{\frac32}}}=\int{\frac{4\cos{\theta}}{64\cos^3{\theta}}}\,d\theta∫(16−x2)23​dx​=∫64cos3θ4cosθ​dθ

(Simplify)

=116∫sec⁡2θ dθ=\frac{1}{16}\int{\sec^2{\theta}}\,d\theta=161​∫sec2θdθ

(Evaluate the integral)

=116tan⁡θ+C.=\frac{1}{16}\tan{\theta}+C\text.=161​tanθ+C.

The final step is to express this result in terms of xxx.

We can do this using a reference triangle showing the relationship between xxx and θ\thetaθ:

sin⁡θ=x4\sin{\theta}=\frac{x}{4}sinθ=4x​
tan⁡θ=x16−x2\tan{\theta}=\frac{x}{\sqrt{16-x^2}}tanθ=16−x2​x​

Using this triangle, we see that tan⁡θ=x16−x2\tan{\theta}=\frac{x}{\sqrt{16-x^2}}tanθ=16−x2​x​. This implies that

∫dx(16−x2)32=116tan⁡θ+C=x1616−x2+C\int{\frac{dx}{(16-x^2)^{\frac32}}}=\frac{1}{16}\tan{\theta}+C=\frac{x}{16\sqrt{16-x^2}}+C∫(16−x2)23​dx​=161​tanθ+C=1616−x2​x​+C

Integrals involving a2+x2a^2+x^2a2+x2 or x2−a2x^2-a^2x2−a2

Contains...Corresponding SubstitutionUseful Identity
a2−x2a^2-x^2a2−x2x=asin⁡θx=a\sin{\theta}x=asinθ, π2≤θ≤π2\frac{\pi}{2}\leq\theta\leq\frac{\pi}{2}2π​≤θ≤2π​a2−a2sin⁡2θ=a2cos⁡2θa^2-a^2\sin^2{\theta}=a^2\cos^2{\theta}a2−a2sin2θ=a2cos2θ
a2+x2a^2+x^2a2+x2x=atan⁡θx=a\tan{\theta}x=atanθ, −π2≤θ≤π2-\frac{\pi}{2}\leq\theta\leq\frac{\pi}{2}−2π​≤θ≤2π​a2+a2tan⁡2θ=a2sec⁡2θa^2+a^2\tan^2{\theta}=a^2\sec^2{\theta}a2+a2tan2θ=a2sec2θ
x2−a2x^2-a^2x2−a2x=asec⁡θx=a\sec{\theta}x=asecθ, {0≤θ≤π2for x≥aπ2<θ≤πfor x≤−a\begin{cases} 0\leq\theta\leq\frac{\pi}{2}&\text{for }x\geq a\\\frac{\pi}{2}<\theta\leq\pi&\text{for }x\leq-a\end{cases}{0≤θ≤2π​2π​<θ≤π​for x≥afor x≤−a​a2sec⁡2θ−a2=a2tan⁡2θa^2\sec^2{\theta}-a^2=a^2\tan^2{\theta}a2sec2θ−a2=a2tan2θ
